title: How to Take Steps to Be Clean and Green

steps.headline: Update your washer and dryer.
steps.description: Laundry needs are the second-biggest water user in a home. Energy-efficient machines can save big on utility bills, and the technologies employed in those machines also can be gentler to your clothes, help you use less detergent and reduce drying time.

steps.headline: Keep your water heater warm.
steps.description: Wrapping a water heater with insulation can keep as many as 1,000 pounds of global-warming CO2 a year out of the upper atmosphere

steps.headline: Give your clothing a cold shower!
steps.description: Using cold water can save up to 80 percent of the energy required to wash clothes.

steps.headline: Use vinegar in your washer.
steps.description: A cup of vinegar will clean a washing machine. Run it through a regular cycle -- but not with clothes.

steps.headline: See if your dry cleaners are green.
steps.description: There are several dry cleaners that now use less chemicals to clean your suits and dresses. Find one that supports green dry cleaning in your area.

steps.headline: Clean the coffeemaker.
steps.description: Vinegar will clean out deposits clogging a steam iron or coffeemaker.

steps.headline: Stay away from air fresheners.
steps.description: Some commercial air fresheners use chemicals that can be harmful to your infant's development. Instead, lightly spritz the place with vinegar

steps.headline: Pick an energy-efficient home.
steps.description: When looking for a home to purchase, look for green features, such as Built Green and Energy Star certification. Or ask to see the last year's utility bills to get a sense of the home's current efficiency.

steps.headline: Use a laptop whenever possible.
steps.description: A laptop uses a fraction of the power required by a desktop computer.

steps.headline: Tune off that stove.
steps.description: Generating enough electricity to cook for an hour in an electric oven creates 2.7 pounds of carbon dioxide. Here's a list of what can do it for less: toaster oven, 1.3 pounds over 50 minutes; slow cooker, 0.9 pounds over seven hours; and microwave, 0.5 pounds over 15 minutes.
